hints_html:
A differentiable function is increasing on an interval if its derivative is positive on that interval. What would a sign table of the derivative tell you then?

If you don’t like a sign table: In question 2 (a), we determined where f’(x)=0 or does not exist, i.e. the critical points of f(x). Try testing the sign of f’ for values between two adjacent critical points.
hints_latex:
A differentiable function is increasing on an interval if its derivative
is positive on that interval. What would a sign table of the derivative
tell you then?

\textbf{If you don't like a sign table:} In question 2 (a), we
determined where \emph{f'(x)=0} or does not exist, i.e. the critical
points of \emph{f(x)}. Try testing the sign of \emph{f}' for values
between two adjacent critical points.
hints_raw:
A differentiable function is increasing on an interval if its derivative is positive on that interval. What would a sign table of the derivative tell you then?
'''If you don't like a sign table:'''
In question 2 (a), we determined where ''f'(x)=0'' or does not exist, i.e. the critical points of ''f(x)''. Try testing the sign of ''f''' for values between two adjacent critical points.
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
Factoring the derivative yields

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{(x-1)(x+1)(x-\sqrt 6)(x+\sqrt 6)}{(x-\sqrt 3)^2(x+\sqrt 3)^2}\end{aligned}\]

Now the following sign table is straight forward:

[c]@llllllll@ & \((-\infty;-\sqrt 6)\) & \((-\sqrt 6; -\sqrt 3)\) & \((-\sqrt 3; -1)\) & \(\displaystyle (-1;1)\) & \((1; \sqrt 3)\) & \((\sqrt 3; \sqrt 6)\) & \((\sqrt 6; \infty)\)
\(\displaystyle x-1\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(\displaystyle x+1\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(x-\sqrt 6\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(x+\sqrt 6\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\((x-\sqrt 3)^2\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\((x+\sqrt 3)^2\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(\displaystyle f'(x)\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
\(\displaystyle f(x)\) & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\)

And so we can conclude that the function is increasing on:

\[\begin{aligned} (- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)\end{aligned}\]

and decreasing on:

\[\begin{aligned} (- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)\end{aligned}\]

If you don’t like a sign table:

From Question 2 (a), we know that the critical points of \(f(x)\), when \(f'(x)\) or does not exist, are at x = \(\pm\)1, \(\pm\), and \(\pm\).

  • Testing a value less than -, such as -3, we get \(f\)’(-3) = 2/3 > 0.

  • Testing a point between - and -, such as -2, yields \(f\)’(-2) = -2 < 0.

  • Testing a point between - and -1, such as -1.5, we get \(f\)’(-1.5) = -25/3 < 0.

  • Finally, we test a point between -1 and 1, such as 0, and get \(f\)’(0) = 2/3 > 0.

Normally, we would have to test points between the positive critical points as well, but since our function only has x2 terms in it (i.e. \(f\)’ is even), we know that our negative test points will have identical values to their corresponding positive test points.

(For example, testing -2 and 2 produce identical values of -2, so \(f(x)\) < 0 between - and - as well as between and .)

Therefore: \(f(x)\) is

  • increasing on the intervals \((- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)\)

and

  • decreasing on the intervals \((- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)\).

Note that the critical points are not included in the intervals of increase and decrease.
sols_latex:
Factoring the derivative yields

\begin{align*}
f'(x) = \frac{(x-1)(x+1)(x-\sqrt 6)(x+\sqrt 6)}{(x-\sqrt 3)^2(x+\sqrt 3)^2}
\end{align*}

Now the following sign table is straight forward:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllllll@{}}
& $(-\infty;-\sqrt 6)$ & $(-\sqrt 6; -\sqrt 3)$ & $(-\sqrt 3; -1)$ &
$\displaystyle (-1;1)$ & $(1; \sqrt 3)$ & $(\sqrt 3; \sqrt 6)$ &
$(\sqrt 6; \infty)$\\
$\displaystyle x-1$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle x+1$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$x-\sqrt 6$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$
& $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle +$\\
$x+\sqrt 6$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$
& $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$\\
$(x-\sqrt 3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$(x+\sqrt 3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle -$ &
$\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \nearrow$ &
$\displaystyle \searrow$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ &
$\displaystyle \nearrow$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ &
$\displaystyle \searrow$ & $\displaystyle \nearrow$\\
\end{longtable}

And so we can conclude that the function is increasing on:

\begin{align*}
(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)
\end{align*} and decreasing
on:

\begin{align*}
(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)
\end{align*}

\textbf{If you don't like a sign table:}

From Question 2 (a), we know that the critical points of $f(x)$,
when $f'(x)$ or does not exist, are at \emph{x} = $\pm$1, $\pm$, and $\pm$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Testing a value less than -, such as -3, we get $f$'(-3) = 2/3
  \textgreater{} 0.
\item
  Testing a point between - and -, such as -2, yields $f$'(-2) = -2
  \textless{} 0.
\item
  Testing a point between - and -1, such as -1.5, we get $f$'(-1.5) =
  -25/3 \textless{} 0.
\item
  Finally, we test a point between -1 and 1, such as 0, and get $f$'(0) =
  2/3 \textgreater{} 0.
\end{itemize}

Normally, we would have to test points between the positive critical
points as well, but since our function only has
\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} terms in it (\emph{i.e. $f$' is even}), we
know that our negative test points will have identical values to their
corresponding positive test points.

(For example, testing -2 and 2 produce identical values of -2, so
$f(x)$ \textless{} 0 between - and - as well as between and .)

\textbf{Therefore:} $f(x)$ is

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  increasing on the intervals
  $(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)$
\end{itemize}

and

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  decreasing on the intervals
  $(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)$.
\end{itemize}

\emph{Note that the critical points are not included in the intervals of
increase and decrease.}

And so we can conclude that the function is increasing on:

(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)

and decreasing on:
:<math>
(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)
</math>
'''If you don't like a sign table:'''

From Question 2 (a), we know that the critical points of &fnof;(''x''), when &fnof;'(''x'') or does not exist, are at ''x'' = &plusmn;1, &plusmn;{{sqrt|6}}, and &plusmn;{{sqrt|3}}. 

* Testing a value less than -{{sqrt|6}}, such as -3, we get &fnof;'(-3) = 2/3 > 0.
* Testing a point between -{{sqrt|6}} and -{{sqrt|3}}, such as -2, yields &fnof;'(-2) = -2 < 0.
* Testing a point between  -{{sqrt|3}} and -1, such as -1.5, we get &fnof;'(-1.5) = -25/3 < 0.
* Finally, we test a point between -1 and 1, such as 0, and get &fnof;'(0) = 2/3 > 0.

Normally, we would have to test points between the positive critical points as well, but since our function only has ''x''<sup>2</sup> terms in it (''i.e. &fnof;' is even''), we know that our negative test points will have identical values to their corresponding positive test points.

<small>(For example, testing -2 and 2 produce identical values of -2, so &fnof;(''x'') < 0 between -{{sqrt|6}} and -{{sqrt|3}} as well as between {{sqrt|3}} and {{sqrt|6}}.)</small>

'''Therefore:''' &fnof;(''x'') is 
* increasing on the intervals <math>(- \infty,-\sqrt 6 ) \cup (-1,1) \cup (\sqrt6,\infty)</math> 
and 
* decreasing on the intervals <math>(- \sqrt 6,-\sqrt 3 ) \cup (-\sqrt 3,-1) \cup (1,\sqrt 3) \cup (\sqrt3,\sqrt 6)</math>.

''Note that the critical points are not included in the intervals of increase and decrease.''
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x^3+x^2-2x-3}{x^2-3}.\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{(x^2-1)(x^2-6)}{(x^2-3)^2}, \qquad f''(x) = \frac{2x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}.\end{aligned}\]

On what intervals is f(x) increasing? On what intervals is f(x) decreasing?
statement_raw:
Consider the function

:<math>f(x) = \frac{x^3+x^2-2x-3}{x^2-3}.</math>

Its first and second derivatives are given by

:<math>f'(x) = \frac{(x^2-1)(x^2-6)}{(x^2-3)^2}, \qquad f''(x) = \frac{2x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}.</math>

On what intervals is f(x) increasing? On what intervals is f(x) decreasing?
